title: Contributors
text:
The team that developed the materials for this website is composed of:

Diego Kozlowski
Laia Domenech Burin
Carolina Pradier
Germán Rosati
Natsumi S. Shokida

We are grateful for their dedication and contributions to this project.
Additionally, these materials were developed at the request of Professor Thema Monroe-White, who provided the funding for the project. We extend our sincere thanks to Thema for her support and encouragement.

title: Materials
text:
As the goal is to compile a selection of materials into a course, the most convenient is to bulk download all the materials from the repository and select the blocks from the folder.
Alternatively, you can check the class notes directly, and download the materials of each block:

title: Setup
text:
To be able to work with these materials, you will need:






Create a github.com account
setup git in your computer




Also, the following packages are needed for many of the materials:

install.packages('tidyverse')

Each materials block use different packages, so be sure to have everything installed beforehand

title: Critical Computational Social Sciences
text:
Building Blocks
The materials consists of 20 building blocks, grouped into six categories

title: Critical Computational Social Sciences
text:
Materials’ structure
Each block consists of four files that aim to develop the theoretical and practical content of the course

title: Open materials for Data Science with a critical perspective
text:
Syllabuses’ examples
Depending on the goals of the course, the students’ profile, and the number of sessions, each block can be taught in one or two sessions. In most of the cases, the theoretical and practical materials come up to a natural division.

title: Setup
text:
class notes
slides or html output

title: Critical Computational Social Sciences
text:
Flexible Syllabus

Depending on the goals of the course, the students’ profile, and the number of sessions, different syllabuses could be built.
Each block can be taught in one or two sessions. The suggested division is between the theoretical and practical parts, although this might not apply to every block.
Below are some examples of possible courses, but many combinations could work!
